content.description:
Visit Up Among the Firs for this climb, stay for the other climbs.  Start up a fairly easy corner, a few awkward moves in a flaring crack lead to a beautiful left facing corner crack. 

The trail that takes you to Up Among the Firs pretty much exits in front of a feature called "The Pie" as there are cracks that section the face the way a pie would be cut into six pieces.  The right side of this area is bounded by a big left facing corner which hosts this climb.
Medium nuts and cams will get you through the initial corner and flare.  The upper crack takes hand sized gear, but note that it widens a bit inside, so choose your gear wisely: what enters the crack may tip out once it's inside.  Don't let  that comment worry you too much, the protection is excellent.

start on the block, move left, then climb the rt side of the slab arete.

starts on large block separating left and right sections of Up Among the Firs
4 bolts

start as for Road Rash, right at the final bolt, move up and right as for Zeasi.

same start as Road Rash, alternative finish really to a tough 10d  of Road Rash.
3 bolts plus gear to one inch

Arete right of A Little Testis. You can skip the mossy slab by hiking around.

8 bolts

climbs.name: Nostalgia Aint What it Used to be

content.description:
enjoyable little pockets to a finger crack

just right of Zaesi, shares anchors with Chokin' a Grogin
two bolts plus gear to two inches

I wasn't sure whether to call this trad or sport as it's entirely bolt protected except for one placement. 
  
 The semi-intimidating arete left of A Little Testis. 
  
 Slab past the first two bolts of Unusual panic which will seem like the crux if you're dialed in to Squamish slabs.  After the 2nd bolt, veer right towards a crack where the slab meets a bolted arete at a left facing corner.  Place a #2 Camalot sized piece (w/ runner) in the corner then continue up the corner until you can clip the first bolt on the arete.  Transition onto the arete and enjoy clean face climbing (w/ holds) until you top out at anchors.

A few feet left of the Testis corner.
About 7 bolts and one hand sized piece.

climb the left side of the slab with difficulty passing the final bolt.

left most bolted line on slab of rock at Up Among the Firs.
3 bolts plus gear to one inch

climbs.name: Toasted Testa Rossa
climbs.fa: Jason Lin and Marilyn Geninatti,  August 2011

content.description:
Start as for Road Rash on mossy 5.7 slab heading left and up to crack. Roof protects with a couple nuts or up to a #2 cam and then cruise the nice crack to shared anchors with Collet a Day and Road Rash.

Far left of Up Among the Firs
small to medium passive or active gear. Upper crack widens, so a #3 could be used.

Climb the bolted slab up the left side of the main wall past 10 bolts to a bolted anchor (you will probably want to extend the anchor with slings to TR). Crux is up at the top. Low angle but small holds makes you trust your feet.

Left of Wicker Cranium. Uses the same achor.
10 Bolts. Chains on the anchors.

Thin slab leads to super thin pure friction.

First bolted line to the right of Wicker Cranium. Shares the same anchor.
Bolts. Maybe a finger cam for the runout. Anchor.

This is a fun route, and one of my favorites in Murin Park: the finger locks and hand jams are sweet, it eats gear, and like a lot of classic 'squish routes, the crux comes... Well, I'll let you find that one out for yourself. Rest assured, this is a very safe route. The lower half of the crack can be very wet after rain or during any month not named June, July, August, or September, but after hiking all the way up there, you're going to climb it anyway, so who cares, right? This route is the obvious dogleg on the blank slab to the left of A Little Testis and just to the right of a line of shiny new bolts that terminate at the same anchors. TCUs, cams to 2.5", set of nuts. Fixed anchor at the top, from which you can rap or TR with a 60.

This climb looks promising from below and does have a cool gear protected finger and hand traverse, but its character changes completely to a low angle but brutally thin friction affair.

Left of "The Pie" area, but before the next smooth wall there is a rectangular alcove.  Start up the right side corner.
Gear from nuts to a 3" cam for the initial corner and traverse.  Quickdraws for the second half.

climb center crack line and finish past one bolt on the slab

center crack line on left slab
one bolt plus gear to one inch

A beautiful crag above the Petrifying Wall.  It feels a little more remote as the highway noise is almost completely damped out and is in a pretty forest.  It has a pretty even mix of trad and sport. 
  
 Some highlights include "Wicker Cranium" (5.9 trad) "A Little Testis" (5.10b trad) and "Totally Clips" (5.10b sport).
